articles.headline: George Floyd’s Family Settles Suit Against Minneapolis for $27 Million
articles.snippet: The settlement is one of the largest of its kind, but it may make it harder to seat an impartial jury for the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer charged with murder in Mr. Floyd’s death.
articles.abstract: The settlement is one of the largest of its kind, but it may make it harder to seat an impartial jury for the trial of Derek Chauvin, the former officer charged with murder in Mr. Floyd’s death.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Watch Live: Derek Chauvin on trial for George Floyd’s Death]
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and John Eligon

articles.headline: Why Al Franken Hovers Over the Debate About Cuomo’s Future
articles.snippet: When the Minnesota senator resigned, Democrats weighed how to handle sexual misconduct allegations. Now that conversation is evolving, with Gov. Andrew Cuomo at the center.
articles.abstract: When the Minnesota senator resigned, Democrats weighed how to handle sexual misconduct allegations. Now that conversation is evolving, with Gov. Andrew Cuomo at the center.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephanie Miner is no friend of Andrew Cuomo.

articles.headline: Biden Takes First Tentative Steps to Address Global Vaccine Shortage
articles.snippet: Under pressure to play catch-up on “vaccine diplomacy,” President Biden says he will help finance vaccine manufacturing capacity but is still resisting exports of doses.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to play catch-up on “vaccine diplomacy,” President Biden says he will help finance vaccine manufacturing capacity but is still resisting exports of doses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden, under intense pressure to donate excess coronavirus vaccines to needy nations, moved on Friday to address the global shortage in another way, partnering with Japan, India and Australia to expand global vaccine manufacturing capacity.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: A Last-Minute Add to Stimulus Bill Could Restrict State Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: Republicans say Congress is infringing on state sovereignty by trying to limit the ability of local governments to control their finances.
articles.abstract: Republicans say Congress is infringing on state sovereignty by trying to limit the ability of local governments to control their finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A last-minute change in the $1.9 trillion economic relief package that President Biden signed into law this week includes a provision that could temporarily prevent states that receive government aid from turning around and cutting taxes.

articles.headline: From Crypto Art to Trading Cards, Investment Manias Abound
articles.snippet: Each market frenzy seems crazier than the last. But all have the same roots.
articles.abstract: Each market frenzy seems crazier than the last. But all have the same roots.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Maggots, Rape and Yet Five Stars: How U.S. Ratings of Nursing Homes Mislead the Public
articles.snippet: Nursing homes have manipulated the influential star system in ways that have masked deep problems — and left them unprepared for Covid-19.
articles.abstract: Nursing homes have manipulated the influential star system in ways that have masked deep problems — and left them unprepared for Covid-19.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, the U.S. government introduced a powerful new tool to help people make a wrenching decision: which nursing home to choose for loved ones at their most vulnerable. Using a simple star rating — one being the worst, five the best — the system promised to distill reams of information and transform an emotional process into one based on objective, government-blessed metrics.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Can France’s Far Right Rise to Power? One Mayor Shows How.
articles.snippet: In the southern city of Perpignan, voters who had long built a dam against the far right turned in the last election. Some wonder whether it’s a harbinger of things to come.
articles.abstract: In the southern city of Perpignan, voters who had long built a dam against the far right turned in the last election. Some wonder whether it’s a harbinger of things to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — Riding high in the polls ahead of the next presidential election, feeling they’ve won the battle over ideas, smelling blood in the Élysée Palace, leaders of France’s far right cocked their eyes across the land at perhaps the one thing standing between them and power: beavers.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: Two Decades After the ‘End of Welfare,’ Democrats Are Changing Direction
articles.snippet: The pandemic and a set of other economic and social forces changed the calculation for Democrats when it comes to government aid. The question now is how long the moment will last.
articles.abstract: The pandemic and a set of other economic and social forces changed the calculation for Democrats when it comes to government aid. The question now is how long the moment will last.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A quarter-century ago, a Democratic president celebrated “the end of welfare as we know it,” challenging the poor to exercise “independence” and espousing balanced budgets and smaller government.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Jason DeParle

articles.headline: ‘I’d Much Rather Be in Florida’
articles.snippet: Floridians are out and about and pandemic restrictions have been lifted. There’s just one problem: The virus never went away.
articles.abstract: Floridians are out and about and pandemic restrictions have been lifted. There’s just one problem: The virus never went away.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: The Imperious Rise and Accelerating Fall of Andrew Cuomo
articles.snippet: Even as he tries to plot a political survival strategy in the face of sexual misconduct allegations, Mr. Cuomo is an object lesson on the dangers of kicking people on the way up.
articles.abstract: Even as he tries to plot a political survival strategy in the face of sexual misconduct allegations, Mr. Cuomo is an object lesson on the dangers of kicking people on the way up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring, when the coronavirus outbreak was surging in New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s daily briefings became appointment television for many, as he authoritatively ticked through the latest statistics on infections, hospital beds and deaths.

articles.headline: Korean TV’s Unlikely Star: Subway Sandwiches
articles.snippet: The sandwich chain’s aggressive use of product placement has made it a ubiquitous presence on the country’s television shows.
articles.abstract: The sandwich chain’s aggressive use of product placement has made it a ubiquitous presence on the country’s television shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an episode of the Korean television show “The K2,” which takes place in a world of fugitives and bodyguards, a man is being treated with a defibrillator when he enters into a dream state. On the fringe of death, he recalls taking a past love to a Subway restaurant and to a park for a picnic, where he gently feeds her a sandwich and soft drink with the Subway logo facing the camera.

articles.headline: The Swag Must Go On: Hollywood’s Pandemic Oscar Campaign
articles.snippet: “There is a why-are-we-even-doing-this feeling,” one industry insider said of jockeying for nominations, to be announced on Monday.
articles.abstract: “There is a why-are-we-even-doing-this feeling,” one industry insider said of jockeying for nominations, to be announced on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As a potential Oscar nominee for film editing, William Goldenberg should be feeling dizzy right about now. So many tastemaker cocktail parties to attend. So many panel discussions to participate in.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Police Shrugged Off the Proud Boys, Until They Attacked the Capitol
articles.snippet: Two Proud Boys accused of leading a mob to Congress followed a bloody path to get there. Law enforcement did little to stop them.
articles.abstract: Two Proud Boys accused of leading a mob to Congress followed a bloody path to get there. Law enforcement did little to stop them.
articles.lead_paragraph: A protester was burning an American flag outside the 2016 Republican convention in Cleveland when Joseph Biggs rushed to attack. Jumping a police line, he ripped the man’s shirt off and “started pounding,” he boasted that night in an online video.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Piers Morgan Can’t Wait to Bring the Worst of America Home
articles.snippet: British TV executives see opportunity — and money to be made — in bringing American cable-style clashes to their screens.
articles.abstract: British TV executives see opportunity — and money to be made — in bringing American cable-style clashes to their screens.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Piers Morgan stormed off the set of “Good Morning Britain” last week as a Black colleague chided him for “trashing” Meghan Markle, it felt like a familiar American scene: a tone-deaf old-timer getting swept aside by an anti-racist younger generation, as the culture of media changes.

articles.headline: New Suitor May Enter Fray for Tribune Publishing
articles.snippet: A Maryland hotel magnate who had a deal to buy The Baltimore Sun is now weighing a bid for all of Tribune’s newspapers that could thwart a hedge fund’s plan.
articles.abstract: A Maryland hotel magnate who had a deal to buy The Baltimore Sun is now weighing a bid for all of Tribune’s newspapers that could thwart a hedge fund’s plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: A deal that would reshape the American newspaper industry has run into complications just one month after an agreement was reached, according to three people with knowledge of the matter. As a result, the New York hedge fund Alden Global Capital may have to fend off a new suitor for Tribune Publishing, the chain that owns major metropolitan dailies across the country, including The Chicago Tribune, The Daily News and The Baltimore Sun, the people said.

articles.headline: On Mexico’s Border With U.S.,Desperation as Migrant Traffic Piles Up
articles.snippet: Mexico is struggling to deal with a new wave of migrants expelled from the U.S. while even more come north hoping to cross. Shelters that were empty four months ago are now having to turn many away.
articles.abstract: Mexico is struggling to deal with a new wave of migrants expelled from the U.S. while even more come north hoping to cross. Shelters that were empty four months ago are now having to turn many away.
articles.lead_paragraph: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — The migrants’ hopes have been drummed up by human smugglers who promise that President Biden’s administration will welcome them.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: Uncounted in the Unemployment Rate, but They Want to Work
articles.snippet: Millions have left the labor force in the last year, many home with children or health concerns. The statistics may not reflect their aspirations.
articles.abstract: Millions have left the labor force in the last year, many home with children or health concerns. The statistics may not reflect their aspirations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Hesse was expecting an imminent promotion to manager of Sub Zero Ice Cream, a nitrogen ice cream shop in Ventura, Calif., when it shut down in March because of the pandemic.

articles.headline: How the U.S. Got It (Mostly) Right in the Economy’s Rescue
articles.snippet: Though the recession has been painful, policymakers cushioned the pandemic’s blow and opened the way to recovery.
articles.abstract: Though the recession has been painful, policymakers cushioned the pandemic’s blow and opened the way to recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic ripped a hole in the economy a year ago, many feared that the United States would repeat the experience of the last recession, when a timid and short-lived government response, in the view of many experts, led to years of high unemployment and anemic wage growth.

articles.headline: Brazil Needs Vaccines. China Is Benefiting.
articles.snippet: China is a major supplier of coronavirus vaccine, giving it enormous leverage in pandemic-ravaged nations. Brazil, recently hostile to the Chinese company Huawei, has suddenly changed its stance.
articles.abstract: China is a major supplier of coronavirus vaccine, giving it enormous leverage in pandemic-ravaged nations. Brazil, recently hostile to the Chinese company Huawei, has suddenly changed its stance.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — China was on the defensive in Brazil.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
